turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I need to book a hotel in Chicago for 3 nights, checking in on July 12th. Needs to have a pool and free breakfast. This is for two adults and one child.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, I am searching for hotels in Chicago for 3 nights, checking in on July 12th, for 2 adults and 1 child, with a pool and free breakfast. One moment...

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Great! Hopefully, something not too expensive. Last time I booked, I got totally ripped off. Is there any way to guarantee that the pictures shown are accurate?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your concern. While I cannot *guarantee* the absolute accuracy of hotel-provided images, I can filter for hotels with consistently high review scores regarding cleanliness and amenities. This often correlates with accurate representation in their photos. Would you like me to add that filter?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yes, please do that. Also, what happens if I book a non-refundable room and then, say, the hotel is undergoing construction when I arrive? Am I just out of luck?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid question. While non-refundable rooms typically don't allow cancellations for personal reasons, significant issues like undisclosed construction often warrant a refund or compensation. In such cases, I recommend contacting the hotel directly upon arrival to explain the situation. If they are uncooperative, contact our customer support immediately with photographic evidence, and we will advocate on your behalf. Many hotels will attempt to rectify the problem by offering an alternative room or, in severe cases, a refund. I am showing you a few options now, all with high cleanliness/amenity scores.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, good to know. These look promising. Thanks for the help!
